text.sentence: Basic Industries | U.S. Metals and Mining fourteen August two thousand fifteen

Overall we see CF's two most recent major transactions as proactive and positive, demonstrating that management has no intention of resting on past laurels: Just as the Street was starting to get its arms around the CF/OCI combination and the added breadth of product and geography that it adds, Wednesday morning CF announced a substantial off take agreement plus a dollar two.eight billion equity buy in with the CHS co op, one of its major customers ­ that also appears to coincide with the cancellation of CHS's proposed greenfield ammonia plant in North Dakota.
In a commodities/materials world that's rapidly changing, we are encouraged that CF clearly doesn't intend to simply play defense going into the next cycle.

The initial response to the OCI deal was mixed, but the strategic benefits are substantial: Many clients who had become comfortable with the execution plus cashflow story that had come to define CF now face a more complicated entity with higher cost European production, methanol exposure, and a pause in share buybacks.
What's more, dollar eight.twoB for what looks to be roughly dollar nine hundredM in eventual incremental EBITDA ­ much from assets that haven't yet started up ­ is a healthy price.

Yet through this transaction CF gains control of the most prominent greenfield N plant in the Midwest ­ adding some inoculation against expanded domestic UAN supply and adds tax efficiency through a UK domicile and a Dubai based trading company.
Our preliminary numbers imply that management's cash flow accretion guidance looks realistic.
The arrangement with CHS further de risks CF's expansion projects and provides a healthy amount of up front cash: CHS essentially gains an eight.nine
percent claim on CF's operating income for dollar two.eight billion, while CF gets a locked in buyer of one.sevenmm
Together, these deals highlight that CF recognizes the need to combine a low cost position with the distribution breadth and market influence needed to protect that position.
Assuming the transactions complete as expected, we look for the stock to outperform the group.

We believe CF is well positioned as a global nitrogen producer advantaged by low cost North American natural gas, and that investors will increasingly incorporate the impact of CF's share repurchases and organic growth scheduled for two hundred one thousand five hundred sixteen.
Still, crop prices have trended lower, adding uncertainty around fertilizer prices and demand in the near term.
Our upside case of dollar eighty one uses a seven.x
forward multiple applied to a projected two thousand sixteen EBITDA of dollar three.twenty
fourB, which assumes higher nitrogen pricing and lower natural gas costs.
Our downside case of dollar forty three uses a seven.fivex
forward multiple applied to a projected two thousand sixteen EBITDA of dollar one.eightyB,

With these transactions CF becomes a larger, lower risk, more flexible producer with a still strong cash flow outlook

All things considered, we look at CF's activity this way: across our coverage, materialsfocused companies and their stocks have been severely buffeted by an inability to adjust to changing market dynamics.
The Chinese growth demand function appears to be flat lining, and all the supply expansions that seemed to be such high return investments when they started now weigh heavily on prices.

In contrast, the nitrogen market in the U.S. has had a much different fortune as companies like CF have harvested great profitability from the combination of a low cost base that exploits low U.S. energy costs plus a domestic net short N position that supports pricing.
This is changing ­ new supply is coming on line, albeit with less speed and amplitude than many expected, and Chinese production and exports have grown as a significant influence on domestic prices.

Going forward, we expect the winners in the U.S. nitrogen markets to show the same qualities that allow other materials companies to thrive in markets with global surpluses ­ the right product mix, an advantaged cost position, depth of relationships with customers, and a lean, efficient distribution model.
Over this past week we see CF as taking major steps to ensure that it stays ahead of the field in anticipating these kinds of changes.
We'd much rather invest in a company that's proactive in adapting to the market than one that's reactive and wondering how to recapture the prime position it previously had.
Our FY two thousand fifteen/sixteen estimates for CF move higher as the gain from lower natural gas costs offset slightly lower assumed nitrogen product prices.
Anticipating these transactions, we believe CF's risk profile improves, justifying a slightly higher EV/EBITDA multiple of seven.fivex
Combined with slightly higher long term growth potential we increase our price target to dollar seventy oneand upgrade the shares to Overweight from Equal Weight.
Many moving pieces to the CF/OCI transaction, but the overall balance looks compelling

By acquiring OCI N.V.'s U.S., European, and Dubai assets in a combination of stock and cash and re domiciling the new company in the UK, new CF can lower its effective income tax rate to twenty percent from thirty five percent .
ton nitrogen plant opening in Iowa in oneQsixteen, a two.sixmm
ton capacity facility in the Netherlands that produces ammonia, urea, AN/CAN, and melamine, a seventy nine.nine
ton methanol plant in Beaumont, TX, an adjacent, under construction one.ninemm
ton capacity methanol plant planned to open in two thousand seventeen, and a global trading office located in a tax free zone of Dubai.
We've found that our conversations on this transaction essentially reveal investors' preexisting bull/bear thinking about the North American nitrogen market.

If you already held a relatively favorable view ­ you expected U.S. supply to grow but not overwhelm the import balance, saw natural gas prices as remaining advantageously low, and believed in CF's ability to extract better than index realizations ­ then you see enough positive elements of a combined CF/OCI that the deal makes sense.
If instead you've been more convinced that the prospects of a less import dependent U.S. and a more export friendly China are daunting to future N margins, you see elements that reinforce that view.

Our take is that this is a fairly richly priced acquisition that nonetheless adds enough strategically and has sufficient margin of safety financially ­ especially when taking advantage of the tax benefits ­ to make it attractive.
The key for us is that by taking a proactive move to fold in a major greenfield project before it ramps up, we expect CF to
Barclays | CF Industries Holdings manage the urea/UAN mix very effectively in the aim of maintaining market balance.
Expanding the export potential for Donaldsonville only adds to the levers available to ensure that N.A. remains appropriately supplied.
The Relative Negatives · At dollar eight.two billion, this is not a cheap deal when considering that a reasonable estimate for
additive OCI EBITDA once Wever, Natgasoline, and the Beaumont expansions are all up and running by two thousand seventeen is roughly dollar nine hundredM.

operations, as it's dependent on European natural gas prices that have softened over the past year with the decline in oil but remain elevated vs. the input costs enjoyed by the North American core of CF's production capacity.
Geleen also produces products such as melamine, which is a much different product than nitrogen fertilizers.

supply/demand profile compared to ammonia ­ a potentially higher rate of demand growth but arguably greater oversupply potential ­ and a further expansion of CF's product portfolio outside of fertilizer sales that may not be attractive to investors.
the near medium term stability of the U.S. nitrogen market than they've previously indicated, and that consolidation is needed to stem the tide of greater supply build out and lower margins.
The Relative Positives · Adding the Iowa Fertilizer plant places one of North America's largest and most
Together, the CF/OCI entity would have a commanding position in the roughly fourteenmm ton U.S. UAN market; post the Donaldsonville expansion, CF will have seven.fourmm
tons of UAN capacity, and we'd estimate Wever adds an additional one.two
Together this would represent more than sixty percent of the market and, importantly, also reflect the capability to flex between UAN, urea, and other nitrogen products as domestic demand fluctuates.

new CF to pay a substantially lower UK tax rate, and we'd expect other tax efficient strategies to prove valuable over time ­ exporting product from Donaldsonville to markets in Europe or Latin America via Dubai, for example.
production platform in Europe ­ including UAN ­ and a major presence in the region's CAN market.
We anticipate opportunities by which low cost U.S. produced supply can be shipped to Europe and compete effectively with the region's higher cost producers, even after absorbing freight costs.

inversion structure, the company still expects to have substantial cash available for other growth projects and capital returns in the three four years after the transaction closes ­ CF's forecasts indicate dollar eight.
dollar nine.fiveB for the period two thousand sixteen through two thousand nineteen.
Barclays | CF Industries Holdings a key consideration for CF investors who have become accustomed to the company's regular and substantial buybacks.
The company expects cash flow accretion mid tohigh teens... immediately, and we can reach similar numbers with rough, early pro forma estimates, as shown below.

We expect the main risks for this transaction to be regulatory.
First there are the domestic anti trust issues, given the higher concentration of the nitrogen market in the U.S. ­ particularly of UAN ­ that the combined company would control.
That said, for N as a whole CF/OCI will be the single largest producer but still control less than a third of the market, according to CRU/Fertilizer Week estimates.
The remaining balance would be split between imports and the summed output of all other domestic producers.
The company expects the broader market definition to carry the day.
In Europe we don't consider there to be substantial anti trust risk.
As to the political risk around the inversion, CF has been very careful to manage to the letter of the law in meeting all requirements around the new ownership mix .
Senator Durbin of Illinois could seek to push the issue ­ he's a noted opponent to inversion deals, and CF is currently headquartered in his home state .

Yet there's little outside of political pressure that can be applied; CF points out that unlike other inversions, this deal does not include an attempt to repatriate overseas cash nor shift substantial intellectual property overseas.
The CHS buy in/off take agreement caught the market by surprise, looks effective in further de risking new capacity

While still digesting the OCI deal, CEO Tony Will and team added a new layer to the transformation process by reaching an agreement by which CHS Inc., a large U.S. farmer coop, would invest dollar two.eightB into CF and receive a supply agreement for up to one.sevenmm
CF will then make semi annual payments to CHS as a minority investor commensurate with the gross profit made from the sales of these tons.

Simultaneously with this announcement, CHS also announced separately that it was giving up on the development of its Spiritwood, ND greenfield nitrogen plant, a dollar threeB project that had been stalled due to escalating costs.
easing the marketing task for the new tons produced by Donaldsonville and Port Neal.
The rough implied valuation of dollar two.eightB for an effective eight.nine
percent stake in CF is a nice headline metric, but we don't expect this to become a new benchmark for CF's market value.
Our new dollar seventy one price target reflects a weighted average of two valuation methodologies, a seven.fivex
EV multiple on our two thousand sixteenE EBITDA estimate of dollar two.seventy three billion, implying a dollar seventy two stock price, and a discounted cash flow model with a WACC of eight.four

percent and a long term growth rate of two.five percent, implying a dollar seventy stock price.. Our previous dollar sixty four price target reflects a weighted average of two valuation methodologies, a seven.x
EV multiple on our two thousand sixteenE EBITDA estimate of dollar two.six billion, implying a dollar sixty four stock price, and a discounted cash flow model with a WACC of eight.four

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.

Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.

EV multiple on our two thousand sixteenE EBITDA estimate of dollar two.seventy three billion, implying a dollar seventy two stock price, and a discounted cash flow model with a WACC of eight.four

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Price Target: An overall slowdown in economic growth, a lack of producer discipline leading to an over supply of nutrients, a spike in natural gas prices, or a greater than expected fall in crop/fertilizer prices could cause CF Industries to perform materially lower than our expectations.
